metadata.title: Influence of MIL-53 on the catalytic performance of metallocene in propylene polymerization

Influence of MIL-53 on the catalytic performance of metallocene in propylene polymerization Jeong Suk Lee Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation a Clinton Manianglung Writing – review & editing Validation Data curation b Hye In Jeon Validation Investigation b Young Soo Ko Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan 31080, South Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Kongju National University Cheonan 31080 South Korea aDepartment of Chemical Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan 31080, South Korea b Department of Future Convergence Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan 31080, South Korea Department of Future Convergence Engineering Kongju National University Cheonan 31080 South Korea bDepartment of Future Convergence Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan 31080, South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. In this study, we investigate the application of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a support for metallocene catalysts in the polymerization of propylene. MOFs such as MIL-53 and other conventional supports, SBA-15 and SiO2, were employed to immobilize the Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst activated with methylaluminoxane (MAO). The effects of the physicochemical properties of these supports on catalytic performance and polymer properties were investigated. MIL-53, characterized by its channel structure, facilitated higher molecular weight polypropylene production and exhibited double the catalytic activity of SBA-15 and SiO2 supports. The MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst also demonstrated higher comonomer incorporation and lower polymer melting points. The higher activity, elevated molecular weight, and increased reactivity towards 1-hexene of the MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst are attributed to the electronic and steric effects of MIL-53. This study underscores the significant role of MOF structure in influencing polymerization behavior and highlights the potential of MOF-supported catalysts for tailored polymer properties. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metallocene catalyst MIL-53 Silica Propylene polymerization Polypropylene Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Polypropylene (PP) is typically manufactured using traditional Ziegler-Natta or metallocene/MAO catalysts [1]. Generally, metallocene catalysts are immobilized on different supports, such as silica [2–10], alumina [11], clay [12], zeolites [13], and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [14,15]. The unique structure of supports has significantly influenced the polymerization activity of catalysts [16]. The highly ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15 resulted in a homogeneous distribution and easier accessibility of active sites for polymerization with (n-BuCp)2ZrCl2 metallocene [8]. The distinct morphology of multilayer graphene/polyethylene composite nanosheets, which resemble a chrysanthemum structure, enhanced polymerization activity by preventing β-hydrogen elimination [17]. It was also reported that clay minerals can serve as specific support materials for activating metallocenes without the need for cocatalyst, MAO. The active sites, found exclusively at the edges of acid-treated montmorillonite platelets, were demonstrated to facilitate the polymerization of polypropylene [12]. Given the established achievements in this field, olefin polymerization using MOF-supported catalysts is considered an underexplored route with significant potential applications [18]. Although still in the exploratory stage, MOFs have shown promising results in coordinative ethylene polymerization and microwave-assisted radical polymerization due to their tunability and versatility [19]. Their uniform yet adjustable structure, customizable chemical environment, and highly dispersed metal nodes indicate the need for systematic investigation [20]. Recent studies have primarily focused on the activity alone and have often lacked characterization, with powder X-ray diffraction analyses being the most performed [21,22]. Despite the exponential growth in MOF research, exploring their potential as catalysts for oligomerization and polymerization remains challenging and is in its early stages. MOF polymerization catalysts have yet to reach commercialization or implementation in industrial processes [22,23]. MOFs such as MIL-101, MIL-53, and ZIF-8 were employed as supports for the metallocene catalyst (n-BuCp)2ZrCl2. The polyethylene (PE) produced with MIL-101 and DETA-MIL-101 exhibited minimal incorporation of 1-hexene, suggesting shape-selective polymerization due to the presence of metallocene/methylaluminoxane species inside their cages. The MIL-53 supported catalyst generated higher molecular weight PE, attributed to its channel structure, in contrast to the cage structure of MIL-101 [24]. This study underscores the significant influence of MOF structure on catalytic behavior and polymer properties. The observed shape-selective polymerization of metallocene/MAO species within the cages highlights the need for further research to explore the influence of MOF structures on catalytic performance. Furthermore, given the distinct differences in PE molecular weight achieved with MIL-53, which can be linked to its unique channel structure, additional studies are essential to optimize MOF-supported metallocene catalysts for tailored polymer properties. In this study, we investigated the effect of MIL-53, with its channel structure, compared to the hexagonal mesoporous structure of SBA-15 and conventionally used amorphous SiO2 as supports. The activated Me2Si(4-Me-2-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst, combined with MAO, was immobilized on these prepared supports. We characterized the supported metallocene catalysts to examine how variations in pore size and shape of the supports influence the resulting polymer structures. The primary objective was to elucidate the underlying mechanisms by which the structural attributes of the supports affect the polymerization behavior of metallocene catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The support MIL-53(Al) (Basolite® A100, Sigma-Aldrich) was used without further purification. SBA-15 was prepared following the synthesis of a previous paper [25]. Amorphous silica was purchased from W.R. Grace & Company and used as received. The metallocene studied was dimethylsilylene-bis(2-methyl-4-phenylindenyl)zirconium dichloride (Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2, PCI), the cocatalyst was methylaluminoxane (MAO, Albemarle), and the organoaluminum compound was triethylaluminum (TEAL, Trich). The previously said main components of the catalyst were used as received. Propylene (SK energy, Korea, 99.999 %) and nitrogen gas (Air Products, Korea, 99.999 %) were utilized after passing them through the Fisher RIDOX oxygen scavenger tube and 5A/13X molecular sieve tube. Toluene (HPLC grade, J.T. Baker) and hexane (HPLC grade, J.T. Baker) solvents were used after distillation under reflux in nitrogen by adding sodium metal and benzophenone. The 1-hexene comonomer was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and moisture was removed using a 13X molecular sieve. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis In a 250 mL round-bottom flask, 20 mL of toluene and 1 g of the support were suspended and mixed with a solution of 0.2 mmol of Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 and 24 mmol of MAO. After immobilization at 70 °C for 3 hr, the catalyst was washed five or more times with 100 mL toluene and vacuum dried at 25 °C. All treatments were conducted in a nitrogen atmosphere. 2.3 Propylene polymerization The propylene polymerization reactions were performed in a 500 mL steel high-pressure reactor with a mechanical stirrer. A solution was prepared in a 500 mL storage bottle by mixing 280 mL of hexane, a specific amount of 1-hexene, and a small amount of TEAL. The solution was injected into the reactor, and the temperature was ramped to 50 °C. A certain amount of catalyst was fed in a slurry state with 5 mL of hexane, and a 10 wt% hexane solution of TEAL was used as a scavenger. The polymerization was started after saturating the reactor with propylene. During the polymerization, the total pressure in the reactor was maintained at 7 bar. After the polymerization, the polymer was vacuum filtered, washed with ethanol, and vacuum dried. 2.4 Characterization of catalysts and polymers The surface areas of the supports and supported metallocene catalysts were measured by Micromeritics ASAP 2010 analyzer. After drying the sample prior to measurement, it was degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 hr. The surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The binding energies of aluminum (Al) and zirconium (Zr) were measured through X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS, MultiLab ESCA 2000 equipped with Al Kα (0.85 eV) and Mg Kα (0.7 eV) sources and Alpha 110 hemispherical electron energy analyzer). The obtained XPS spectra were calibrated based on the carbon (C) 1 s peak at 284.4 eV. The Al and Zr contents in the supported catalyst were analyzed through Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-MS, Perkin-Elmer, Optima 200DV). The metallocene immobilized on the support was confirmed through Fourier-Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR, Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700). A custom-built in situ IR cell, designed for both high vacuum and high-pressure conditions, was utilized for FT-IR spectroscopy. Powder samples for FT-IR analysis were prepared within a glovebox. A powder mixture of the supported metallocene catalyst and potassium bromide (KBr) was pressed into a circular disk under 3 tons of pressure using a 13 mm diameter mold. The in situ IR cell containing the catalyst disk was maintained under vacuum for 30 min to eliminate any physisorbed species. FT-IR spectra were subsequently collected in vacuum within the in situ IR cell in transmittance mode, with each spectrum recorded using 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm⁻¹. The melting temperature of the resulting polymer was obtained using Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC, TA 2010), and a DSC curve was obtained by secondary scanning from 25 to 180 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min to measure the melting point. The comonomer content of the copolymer was measured through 13C-NMR (Bruker AMX-300 FT NMR spectrometer). The molecular weight and molecular weight distribution of the resulting polymer were measured through Gel-Permeation Chromatography (Waters Associates chromatograph, Model ALC-GPC-150C). Lastly, the morphology of the resulting polymer was captured through Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (JEOL, JSM-6335F). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of MOFs supported catalyst The supported metallocene catalysts were prepared using MIL-53, SBA-15, and SiO₂ as supports for the Me₂Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)₂ZrCl₂ metallocene catalyst, which was activated with methylaluminoxane (MAO). The supported catalysts were characterized to evaluate the influence of variations in pore size and shape on the resulting polymer structures. Fig. 1 and Table 1 present the BET analysis results, while Table 2 shows the ICP-MS findings for the support materials and the supported metallocene catalysts. The surface areas of the three supports are in the following order: SBA-15 (796 m²/g) > MIL-53 (653 m²/g) > SiO2 (307 m²/g). The zirconium (Zr) contents supported on SBA-15, MIL-53, and SiO2/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalysts were 89.9, 63.6, and 54.8 μmol/g-cat, respectively. The aluminum (Al) contents were measured to be 4.8, 3.1, and 3.7 mmol/g-cat, respectively. The catalyst supported on SBA-15, which has a larger surface area than MIL-53 and SiO2, exhibited the highest Zr and Al contents. In contrast, the catalyst supported on SiO2, with the smallest surface area, showed the lowest Zr content. The lower Al content in MIL-53 compared to SBA-15 and silica likely arises from the large molecular size of MAO and the smaller pore (channel) size of MIL-53, which hinders the diffusion of MAO into its pores. However, the variation in metal content did not directly correlate with polymerization activity. In addition, the immobilization of the metallocene and MAO on the support materials significantly reduced the surface area, pore size, and pore volume of all three supports. Fig. 2–4 show the FT-IR analysis results of the three supported catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2(A), the peak corresponding to the carboxylic acid, an organic ligand that forms MIL-53, was observed in the range of 1400 to 1700 cm-1 [26,27]. Additionally, the peak of the hydroxyl group associated with the Al metal in MIL-53 was detected at 3700 cm-1. In Fig. 2(B), a new peak corresponding to the C–H stretching of the aromatic group appears in the range of 2800 to 3100 cm-1 after the metallocene catalyst is supported on MIL-53 [28]. Fig. 3 shows the FT-IR analysis results of SBA-15 and SBA-15/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalysts. A sharp peak corresponding to the isolated OH group was observed around 3746 cm-1, along with a broad shoulder-shaped peak due to hydrogen bonding in the vicinity of 3400–3600 cm-1 [29]. In Fig. 3a, C–H stretching peaks at 2906, 2938, and 2984 cm-1 are visible, indicating the presence of trace amounts of template residue in SBA-15. After supporting the metallocene and MAO, new peaks corresponding to the C–H stretching of the aromatic group of the metallocene catalyst appeared at approximately 2858, 3031, and 3064 cm-1. Additionally, a broad peak near 3600 cm⁻¹ was identified, representing the interaction between the π-electron and the hydroxyl group of the aromatic ring. Fig. 4 shows the FT-IR analysis results of SiO2 and SiO2/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalysts. For SiO2 (Fig. 4a), a peak corresponding to the OH group in the range of 3400 to 3600 cm-1 exhibited, similar to SBA-15. In the IR spectrum of the supported catalyst, C–H stretching peaks of the metallocene catalyst were observed around 2858 and 2957 cm-1. Fig. 5 shows the XPS results of the MIL-53, SBA-15, and SiO2/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalysts. The Zr 3d peaks of the Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst appeared at 182.2 eV (Zr 3d 5/2) and 184.5 eV (Zr 3d 3/2), while the Zr 3d binding energies of the three supported catalysts showed a slight deviation, ranging from 182.0 to 182.6 eV (Zr 3d 5/2). This suggests differences in the electronic environments of the catalysts when supported in various nanospace environments. Through BET, ICP, FT-IR, and XPS analyses, along with the preparation method, which includes a washing step, it was confirmed that Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 and MAO were successfully supported within SiO2, SBA-15, and MOF-15, making them suitable for application in propylene-1-hexene copolymerization. 3.2 Propylene-1-hexene copolymerization Table 3 shows the results of propylene-1-hexene copolymerization using the three supported catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6 , the propylene homopolymerization and propylene-1-hexene copolymerization activities of the MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst were more than two times higher compared with SBA-15 and SiO2/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst. The higher activity of the MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 system can be attributed to the binding of Me₂Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)₂ZrCl₂ to the Al sites of MIL-53. As evidenced by XPS analysis, interactions between the Al-OH sites and the metallocene complex are hypothesized to increase the electron density around the Zr center, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Additionally, the Al-OH groups in MIL-53 are uniformly distributed at regular intervals, potentially leading to a consistent distribution of active metallocene sites and an increased number of active sites participating in the polymerization process. Consequently, these electronic and steric effects are believed to enhance the polymerization activity of Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 supported on MIL-53. In contrast, SBA-15 and SiO2 are expected to exhibit relatively lower activity, as the catalyst activation primarily relies on interactions between the metallocene and the aluminum in MAO. 3.3 Characterization of polypropylene Table 3 and Fig. 7 show the measurement results of 1-hexene content and melting point of the produced polymers. The 1-hexene content of the copolymers produced from the catalyst supported on MIL-53, SBA-15, and SiO2 at a C6/C3 molar ratio of 0.1 was measured to be 0.73, 0.67, and 0.61 mol %, respectively. The MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst showed a slightly higher comonomer response than the catalyst supported on SBA-15 or SiO2, and the melting point of the resulting copolymer was also reduced. The melting point of the polymers polymerized with three supported catalysts is shown in Fig. 7. Table 3 and Fig. 8 show the GPC results of the resulting polymers. The polymers produced by the catalyst supported on MIL-53 yield polypropylene having a higher molecular weight than the polymer produced by the catalyst supported on SBA-15 and SiO2. This can be explained by the structural difference of MIL-53. As shown in Fig. 2, the metallocene catalyst and MAO react with the OH group, connecting two AlO6-octahedra to form a catalytically active site. Thus, the active site is bordered by the surrounding AlO6-octahedra. As the polymer chain grows, it is expected to produce high molecular weight polypropylene because the β-H elimination reaction is mitigated due to steric hindrance [29]. The PDI values of the polymers produced by the three supported catalysts were measured in the range of 3.3 to 4.1. Noticeably, the PDI values of SiO2 and MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalysts are slightly lower than the SBA15/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst indicating the formation of more uniform active sites. The morphology of the polymers produced by MIL-53, SBA-15, and SiO2/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalysts and three supported catalysts were observed through SEM and are presented in Fig. 9 . The catalyst supported on MIL-53 and SiO2 showed a spherical morphology, while the catalyst supported on SBA-15 looked like an aggregate of cylindrical and rod-shaped particles. Polymer particles grew similarly to the particle shape of the catalyst. Furthermore, for the catalysts supported on MIL-53 and SiO2, it was observed that the polymer particles became more fragmented as the comonomer molar ratio increased. 3.4 Proposed role of MIL-53 in the supported metallocene catalyst Fig. 10 illustrates the metallocene/MAO catalyst immobilized on supports, MIL-53, SBA-15, and SiO2. It highlights the interaction of the catalyst with the OH groups present on the surfaces of the supports. For SBA-15 and SiO2, the metallocene/MAO catalyst primarily interacts with isolated OH groups on the surface. In contrast, in MIL-53, the catalyst interacts with OH groups linked to the aluminum metal, as indicated in the figure. This structural configuration within the nano spaces of the supports significantly influences the electronic environment and catalytic performance, as evidenced by the variations in binding energies and catalytic activities discussed in the earlier part. The figure aids in understanding the distribution and accessibility of active sites within the supports' pore structures, impacting polymerization performances [30,31]. 4 Conclusions Propylene-1-hexene copolymerizations were conducted with activated Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 supported on various supports, MIL-53, SBA-15, and SiO2. The diverse physical and chemical properties of these supports significantly influenced the polymerization behavior of the resulting metallocene catalysts. Notably, the catalytic activity of the MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst was more than double that of catalysts supported on mesoporous SBA-15 and amorphous SiO2. Furthermore, the polypropylene (PP) obtained from MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 exhibited a higher molecular weight compared to other supported metallocene catalysts. Additionally, low polydispersity index (PDI) values suggested uniformity in the active sites of the catalyst. The MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst achieved higher polymerization activity due to the interaction between its Al-OH sites and the metallocene complex, which enhances electron density around the Zr center and catalytic efficiency. MIL-53 also facilitated a uniform distribution of active sites, leading to polymers with higher molecular weights and better comonomer incorporation. The PP particles demonstrated a tendency to replicate the spherical morphology of MIL-53 and SiO2, with increased fragmentation observed with higher feed ratios of C6/C3 in the system. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we investigate the application of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a support for metallocene catalysts in the polymerization of propylene. MOFs such as MIL-53 and other conventional supports, SBA-15 and SiO2, were employed to immobilize the Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst activated with methylaluminoxane (MAO). The effects of the physicochemical properties of these supports on catalytic performance and polymer properties were investigated. MIL-53, characterized by its channel structure, facilitated higher molecular weight polypropylene production and exhibited double the catalytic activity of SBA-15 and SiO2 supports. The MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst also demonstrated higher comonomer incorporation and lower polymer melting points. The higher activity, elevated molecular weight, and increased reactivity towards 1-hexene of the MIL-53/MAO/Me2Si(2-Me-4-PhInd)2ZrCl2 catalyst are attributed to the electronic and steric effects of MIL-53. This study underscores the significant role of MOF structure in influencing polymerization behavior and highlights the potential of MOF-supported catalysts for tailored polymer properties.

coredata.dc:title: Influence of MIL-53 on the catalytic performance of metallocene in propylene polymerization
